JSON Ontology Schema Design  ### Ontological Modeling in the BLEUE âˆ GRID  **JSON Ontology** provides schema-level definitions and class inheritance for every asset and division:  - **Modularity**: Each sector is modeled as a JSON 'Class,' with divisions, assets, and relations expressed as subclasses or references. - **Inheritance**: Common properties (e.g., rights, oracle links, yield parameters) are shared via `@subClassOf` relationships. - **Relationships**: Asset-to-asset, asset-to-division, and asset-to-bill links are explicitly modeled using semantic `@id` references.  **Sample JSON Ontology Schema** ```json {   "title": "SmartFarmSensor",   "@id": "https://bleuegrid.org/e-agriculture/SmartFarmSensor",   "@type": "Class",   "@subClassOf": "https://bleuegrid.org/e-agriculture/Asset",   "properties": {     "serial_number": { "type": "string" },     "owner": { "type": "string" },     "oracle_endpoint": { "type": "string" },     "vault_allocation": { "type": "string" },     "yield_rate": { "type": "number" },     "bleu_bill_mapping": { "type": "string" }   },   "required": ["serial_number", "owner"] } ``` **Inheritance and Semantics**:  - JSON ontologies are extended with inheritance (`@subClassOf`) and relationships (`@id`), mapping not only structure but also the logic of asset rights and relations. - Through JSON-LD, the schema supports Linked Data, enabling semantic queries across sectors (e.g., "all assets in Vault-Health-03 with yield > 2%").  **Application**:  JSON schemas are used for: - Live API validation and enforcement of registration standards. - Rule-based querying and automation in the MetaVault (OO-logic, business rules). - Export and interoperability across partner ecosystems, e.g., supply chain, finance, and regulatory gateways.  ---  ## VII. JSON Ontology Schema Design  ### Ontological Modeling in the BLEUE âˆ GRID  **JSON Ontology** provides schema-level definitions and class inheritance for every asset and division:  - **Modularity**: Each sector is modeled as a JSON 'Class,' with divisions, assets, and relations expressed as subclasses or references. - **Inheritance**: Common properties (e.g., rights, oracle links, yield parameters) are shared via `@subClassOf` relationships. - **Relationships**: Asset-to-asset, asset-to-division, and asset-to-bill links are explicitly modeled using semantic `@id` references.  **Sample JSON Ontology Schema** ```json {   "title": "SmartFarmSensor",   "@id": "https://bleuegrid.org/e-agriculture/SmartFarmSensor",   "@type": "Class",   "@subClassOf": "https://bleuegrid.org/e-agriculture/Asset",   "properties": {     "serial_number": { "type": "string" },     "owner": { "type": "string" },     "oracle_endpoint": { "type": "string" },     "vault_allocation": { "type": "string" },     "yield_rate": { "type": "number" },     "bleu_bill_mapping": { "type": "string" }   },   "required": ["serial_number", "owner"] } ``` **Inheritance and Semantics**:  - JSON ontologies are extended with inheritance (`@subClassOf`) and relationships (`@id`), mapping not only structure but also the logic of asset rights and relations. - Through JSON-LD, the schema supports Linked Data, enabling semantic queries across sectors (e.g., "all assets in Vault-Health-03 with yield > 2%").  **Application**:  JSON schemas are used for: - Live API validation and enforcement of registration standards. - Rule-based querying and automation in the MetaVault (OO-logic, business rules). - Export and interoperability across partner ecosystems, e.g., supply chain, finance, and regulatory gateways.  ---  ## VII.
